Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Earth Abundant Element Nitride Semiconductors Based on ZnSnN2
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: There exists a poorly understood semiconductor family closely related to the (In,Ga)N family where the column III element is replaced by an ordered cation sublattice composed of equal numbers of Zn and column IV (Si, Ge, Sn) atoms. While the Si- and Ge-containing members have been synthesized, the narrow band-gap member based on Sn -- key to realizing photon absorption and emission in the visible wavelength portion of the spectrum -- has not, limiting the application prospects of this family whose band-gap range is very similar to that of (In,Ga)N. This project is focused on growth and characterization of high-quality single-crystal thin films of zinc tin nitride and the determination of its fundamental optical and electrical properties, particularly with respect to the influence of defects and disorder. Thin films are grown using a plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy technique. Crystallinity and microstructure are evaluated using in-situ reflection high energy diffraction as well as x-ray diffraction and both electron and scanning probe microscopy tools; stoichiometry is evaluated using energy dispersive spectrometry calibrated using ion beam analysis. Optical properties are evaluated using optical absorption and photoluminescence spectroscopy, and electrical characteristics are measured using Hall effect techniques.

Non-technical Description: Many inorganic semiconductor alternatives to silicon solar cells contain indium, an element only three times more abundant than silver and a commodity experiencing significant increases in demand. The II-IV-nitride family in contrast is synthesized from earth-abundant elements for which there already exists significant recycling infrastructure, making it of interest both from economic and environmental perspectives for optoelectronic applications such as photovoltaics and solid state lighting. High-quality samples of new materials also provide important opportunities in the broader semiconductor community to improve our understanding of thin film growth processes, and the nature and role of defects in determining fundamental material properties. Educating students in contemporary issues in semiconductor synthesis and characterization, as well as photovoltaics, provides them with important skills highly relevant to the semiconductor industry and the realization of next-generation devices. Exposing high school students to basic solar cell fabrication provides a valuable pathway to encouraging them to consider careers in science and engineering, while at the same time providing them insight into limitations of current photovoltaic technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A significant proportion of modern optoelectronic devices make use of semiconductor compounds comprised of the metallic elements indium and gallium. For a variety of reasons, the long-term supply of both metals is of global concern, prompting the search for so-called “earth-abundant” alternatives. In this project, we investigated the new compound ZnSnN2, which is composed entirely of earth abundant elements; of particular interest is the fact that zinc (Zn) and tin (Sn) can be sourced through reclamation activity instead of ore extraction. We employed the sophisticated crystal growth technique of plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy (PAMBE) to successfully demonstrate the first synthesis of single crystal thin films of this material, which are necessary for detailed characterization of its electronic and optical properties in preparation for making devices.

Prior to this project, theoretical studies predicted that the material would crystallize in an orthorhombic lattice and have a band gap energy corresponding to the red portion of the visible spectrum. Initial samples produced by PAMBE were not orthorhombic, however, but wurtzitic instead. Working with a new collaborator with experience in computational techniques, we determined that the difference in crystal structure was a sign of partial disorder in the array (sublattice) of zinc and tin atoms. Surprisingly, the calculations also predicted that the disorder had a potential benefit for optoelectronic devices: a reduced band gap energy. In conventional devices such as LEDs and solar cells, the band gap energy (which determines the colors of light the device can utilize) is tuned through alloying, or mixing, of different materials. Instead, the calculations suggested that we had an alternative in this material: tuning through controlled introduction of disorder. As a result, we began to carefully map out the parameter space which defines a typical PAMBE process (substrate temperature, atomic flux ratios, nitrogen species, substrate template), and employed a suite of characterization techniques to correlate them to the crystal structure and material properties.

As a result of this project, we now have direct evidence that we are able to adjust PAMBE growth parameters to vary the degree of disorder in the zinc and tin sublattice. Consequently, we are able to preselect either an orthorhombic or wurtzitic crystal structure during growth. Further, we have seen good agreement with the computational predictions for electronic and optical properties as a function of disorder. These measurements were conducted through collaborations with researchers at the University of Michigan, University of Liverpool, and Binghamton University; students working on the project had the opportunity to interact directly with these research groups, and in several instances, were able to assist with the measurements, gaining valuable experience in contemporary characterization techniques beyond those available at their home institution. One doctoral student (now at the University of Lorraine for postgraduate training) and one masters student (currently working in industry) completed their theses as part of this project. An additional doctoral student began his studies with this project and is currently completing his research. During the course of the project, a number of outreach activities for middle school children were designed and implemented by the PI and his students. These included a “soft circuits” electronics-by-sewing project, a half-day solar cell summer camp, and a hugely popular week-long embedded programming summer camp based on the Raspberry Pi.

We have determined that the band gap of ZnSnN2 can be varied over a significant range through careful selection of parameters for crystal growth. Numerical predictions based on our preliminary experimental work suggest that the band gap energy could be tuned to an exact match for the terrestrial solar spectrum, making the material of interest as a sustainable platform for solar energy. Several other groups are now actively pursuing this goal in addition to ours. From a broader perspective, ZnSnN2 is a member of a family of materials known as ternary heterovalent semiconductors. As such, the insight we have gained into its growth dynamics, and the relationship between growth, disorder and fundamental properties is of benefit to related material systems as well.
